metadata.case_name: Madras Yarn Dealers v. State of Andhra Pradesh
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Petitions Nos. 220, 222, 240 and 380 to 395 of 1955

facts.text: Petitioners are dealers in City of Madras selling yarn to merchants in Andhra Pradesh.
Dealers in Andhra place orders with petitioners in Madras; contracts concluded at Madras; goods delivered ex-godown at Madras; thereafter despatched to purchasers by lorries or rail.

Railway receipts taken in name of consignees and sent by post, or in name of consignor and endorsed to purchasers in Madras or sent by post, or endorsed to bank and purchasers take delivery after payment.
Price of goods paid in Madras in all cases.
Sales are 'Explanation sales' under Explanation to Art. 286(1)(a): property passes outside Andhra but goods delivered in Andhra for consumption.

Andhra State Act 30 of 1953 constituted State of Andhra effective October 1, 1953; Madras General Sales Tax Act continued; Adaptation Order substituted 'Andhra' for 'Madras'; s.22 inserted by Presidential Order July 2, 1952.
Board of Revenue (Commercial Taxes) Andhra issued notification July 13, 1954 calling for returns on Explanation sales; copy to Madras Yarn Merchants Association.
Andhra issued notices June 30, 1955 to petitioners to submit returns by July 15, 1955 or face best judgment assessment and penalties.
Petitions filed July-August 1955 under Art.32 for writ of prohibition restraining tax on inter-State sales under Art.286(2).
Bengal Immunity Co. case judgment September 6, 1955 held Explanation sales are inter-State and not taxable without Parliament lifting ban.
Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 7 of 1956 came into force March 21, 1956 validating State laws for inter-State sales April 1, 1951 to September 6, 1955.
Andhra became Andhra Pradesh under States Reorganisation Act 37 of 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Andhra-Madras Act imposes a tax on Explanation sales.
Whether Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 1956 is ultra vires Art.286(2).
Whether s.22 of Andhra-Madras Act is protected by Validation Act and validates only past levies/collections or authorises future proceedings.
Whether s.22 was null and void ab initio contravening Art.286(2) making proceedings incompetent.
Whether tax on inter-State sales exclusively with Parliament under Entry 42 List I.
Whether tax illegal as single point tax and Madras already taxed.
Whether tax on yarn hit by Essential Commodities Act and Art.286(3).

petitioner_arguments.text: Andhra-Madras Act does not seek to tax Explanation sales; talks only of property passing; s.22 restricts power to tax, does not enlarge definition of sales.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Poppatlal Shah v. State of Madras (1953 SCR 677); Bengal Immunity Co. case (1955 2 SCR 603)

petitioner_arguments.text: Explanation to s.22 like Explanation to Art.286(1)(a) defines outside sales, not inside sales.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bengal Immunity Co. case (1955 2 SCR 603 at 640)

petitioner_arguments.text: Presidential power under Art.372(2) only to conform State laws to Art.286; s.22 cannot permit tax on Explanation sales prohibited by Art.286.
Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 1956 invalid under Art.286(2); Parliament cannot impose sales tax or validate State laws; power only to lift ban prospectively once.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art.286(2); Punjab Province v. Daulat Singh; Behram Khurshed Pesikaka v. State of Bombay (1955 1 SCR 613)

petitioner_arguments.text: Validation Act only saves past levies/collections where both levy and collection within specified period; does not authorise fresh assessments.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dialdas v. Talwalkar AIR 1957 Bom 71; Mettur Industries v. State of Madras AIR 1957 Mad 362

petitioner_arguments.text: s.22 wiped out by Bengal Immunity; no levy to validate.
Tax single point; petitioners paid tax to Madras mills; no second tax.
Petitioners not dealers in Andhra; no sales in Andhra.
Tax on yarn hit by Essential Commodities Act 1952 and Art.286(3).

respondent_arguments.text: s.22 with Explanation enlarges definition of sales to include Explanation sales taxable by delivery State (Andhra).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: United Motors case (1953 SCR 1069); s.22 Andhra-Madras Act

respondent_arguments.text: Art.372(2) Adaptation brings laws into conformity with Art.286 recognizing delivery State taxation.
Validation Act valid under Art.286(2); lifts ban retrospectively; State laws in abeyance not obliterated; authorizes fresh proceedings.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.286(2); Bhikaji Narain v. State of MP (1955 2 SCR 589); legislative power includes retrospective

respondent_arguments.text: s.22 conditional legislation imposing tax once Parliament lifts ban.
No exclusive Parliamentary power over inter-State sales tax; Entry 42 List I not taxation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 42 List I; Entries 82-92 List I

respondent_arguments.text: Pre-Bengal Immunity, Explanation sales treated as intra-State per United Motors.

court_reasoning.text: Dispute confined to Explanation sales; facts not fully investigated but proceed on concession.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sales not all identical; focus on Explanation sales.

court_reasoning.text: s.22 Explanation positive in taxing statute context authorizes tax on Explanation sales as inside sales, unlike restrictive in Art.286(1)(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Context differs: Constitution restricts, statute levies.

court_reasoning.text: s.22 controls s.2(h) definition; deems property passed inside delivery State for Explanation sales; imposes tax conditionally on Parliament lifting ban.
Art.372(2) Adaptation not justiciable; enacts both facets of Art.286(1)(a).
Validation Act lifts ban under Art.286(2); not mere validation but removes fetter retrospectively; legislative power includes retrospective.
Validation Act authorizes proceedings even if no prior levy/collection during period.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deems laws valid; taxes validly levied/collectable.

court_reasoning.text: No exclusive Parliament power; States tax under List II subject to Art.286.

holdings.text: Andhra-Madras Act via s.22 imposes tax on Explanation sales conditionally pending Parliament under Art.286(2).
Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 1956 valid under Art.286(2); lifts ban retrospectively for specified period.
s.22 protected; authorizes initiation of proceedings post-Validation Act even without prior levy.
s.22 not void ab initio; proceedings competent.
Tax on inter-State sales not exclusively Parliament's.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Explanation sales intra-State taxable by delivery State pre-Bengal Immunity

precedents_cited.case_name: Bengal Immunity Co. Ltd. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Explanation does not limit Art.286(2); inter-State sales not taxable without Parliament

precedents_cited.case_name: Poppatlal Shah v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Madras Act pre-amendment taxes only where property passes inside State

precedents_cited.case_name: Bhikaji Narain Dhakras v. State of MP
precedents_cited.relevance: Unconstitutional laws in abeyance, not obliterated

precedents_cited.case_name: Behram Khurshed Pesikaka v. State of Bombay

precedents_cited.relevance: s.22 imposes tax on Explanation sales
s.46 Bombay Act imposes tax conditionally

precedents_cited.case_name: Mathew v. Travancore-Cochin Board of Revenue

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibits State tax on inter-State sales unless Parliament provides; Adaptation powers; writ jurisdiction

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act (Madras 9 of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines sale, turnover, charging section; deems Explanation sales inside State

statutes_cited.name: Sales Tax Laws Validation Act 7 of 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates State laws taxing inter-State sales April 1951-Sept 1955; deems taxes valid

statutes_cited.name: Andhra State Act 30 of 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Continues Madras laws in Andhra; adaptation power

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act 52 of 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Alleged bar on yarn tax with Art.286(3)

outcome.summary: Court holds Andhra-Madras Act s.22 imposes tax on Explanation sales conditionally; Validation Act validly lifts Art.286(2) ban retrospectively authorizing assessments; rejects petitioners' challenges; petitions dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: None; State entitled to proceed with tax.

key_quotes.text: "the Explanation to s. 22 must mean that it authorises the State of Madras to impose a tax on sales falling within its purview."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on positive effect of Explanation in taxing statute

key_quotes.text: "The true scope of the impugned Act is... that it lifts the ban imposed on the States against taxing inter-State sales and not that it validates or ratifies any such law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies Validation Act as lifting ban, not mere validation

key_quotes.text: "s. 22 operated to impose a tax falling within the Explanation, subject to authorisation by Parliament as provided in Art. 286(2)."
key_quotes.speaker: court
